facts.fact: Humpback whales are known for their acrobatic displays, including breaching, tail slapping, and pectoral fin waving, making them a favorite among whale watchers.
Humpback whales are renowned for their haunting and complex songs, which can travel great distances underwater. Each population has its own unique song that evolves over time.
Humpback whales engage in cooperative feeding behaviors, such as bubble-netting, where a group releases bubbles to corral and concentrate prey, making it easier to capture.

Humpback whales undertake extensive migrations, traveling thousands of miles between their feeding and breeding grounds. Their journey takes them from cold polar waters to warmer tropical or subtropical regions.
Humpback whales are known for their altruistic behavior, occasionally intervening to protect other marine animals from predators, such as orcas attacking seals or sea lions.
Humpback whales have distinctive long pectoral fins, which can reach up to one-third of their body length. These fins are used for steering, stabilizing, and performing their impressive acrobatics.

Humpback whales are known to breach with incredible force, launching their massive bodies out of the water and creating a spectacular splash. The reasons for breaching are not fully understood but may include communication or parasite removal.

Despite the end of commercial whaling, humpback whales still face threats such as entanglement in fishing gear, ship strikes, and ocean noise. Conservation efforts are crucial for the continued well-being of these majestic creatures.
